content: Brian Stephen Ssali is a data enthusiast whose interests include data science and machine learning.
summary: Brian Stephen Ssali is a data enthusiast whose interests include data science and machine learning.
title: Brian Stephen  Ssali

content:
We are going to be looking at the water sources in Africa. The data used is from one of the Tidy Tuesdayhere datasets and it can be retrieved from here.We are going to to utilize ggmap, ggplot and leaflet to create spatial maps and use also use the tidyverse packages for data cleaning.
Water sources across Africa
CLZ <- c(RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(name = "Dark2",n = 8),RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(name = "Paired",n = 8))africa_shp %>% rename(country_name = ADM0_NAME) %>% left_join(water_dta %>% count(country_name,water_source) %>% filter(!is.na(water_source)) %>%arrange(country_name,desc(n)) %>% distinct(country_name,.keep_all = T)%>% right_join(africa_shp %>% select(country_name = ADM0_NAME) %>% st_drop_geometry() )%>% mutate(cat = "majority") ) %>%mutate(water_source = case_when(is.na(water_source)~"No data",TRUE~water_source)) %>% ggplot() +geom_sf(aes(fill = water_source))+ggthemes::theme_map()+theme(legend.background =element_rect(fill = NA),legend.position = "bottom")+scale_fill_manual(values = CLZ)
summary: We are going to be looking at the water sources in Africa. The data used is from one of the Tidy Tuesdayhere datasets and it can be retrieved from here.
title: Water Sources in Africa

content:
We are going to look a dataset from the Tidytuesday on the passwords. The dataset entails the actual text of the password,the category of the password,time taken to crack the password(both online and offline) and the strength of the password.
Exploring the datasetWe use the skimr package to have a quick overview of the data with all the data types.
library(skimr)skimr::skim(passwords)(#tab:overview_of_dataset )Data summaryNamepasswordsNumber of rows507Number of columns9_______________________Column type frequency:character3numeric6________________________Group variablesNoneVariable type: character
skim_variablen_missingcomplete_rateminmaxemptyn_uniquewhitespacepassword70.994905000category70.994190100time_unit70.9947070Variable type: numeric
skim_variablen_missingcomplete_ratemeansdp0p25p50p75p100histrank70.99250.50144.481.00125.75250.50375.25500.00▇▇▇▇▇value70.995.608.441.293.433.723.7292.27▇▁▁▁▁offline_crack_sec70.990.502.660.000.000.000.0829.27▇▁▁▁▁rank_alt70.99251.22145.051.00125.75251.50376.25502.00▇▇▇▇▇strength70.997.435.420.006.007.008.0048.00▇▁▁▁▁font_size70.9910.303.650.0010.0011.0011.0028.00▁▇▁▁▁There are some rows with NAs that we are going to remove.It would be interesting to see the how long the passwords take to be cracked based on their corresponding categories and their strength as well
plot1 <- passwords %>%filter(!is.na(category)) %>%mutate(time_unit = factor(time_unit, levels = c("seconds", "minutes", "hours", "days", "weeks", "months", "years"))) %>%ggplot(aes(category, value, fill = time_unit)) +geom_point(aes(colour = time_unit), size = 2.5) +coord_polar(clip = "on") +theme_dark() +theme(legend.position = "bottom", axis.text = element_text(colour = "black"), panel.grid.major = element_line("gray")) +scale_colour_manual(values = c("#FFDB6D", "#C4961A", "#F4EDCA", "#D16103", "#00AFBB", "#4E84C4", "#FC4E07"), guide = guide_legend(nrow = 1))plot1passwords %>%filter(!is.na(category)) %>%group_by(category) %>%transmute(strength = mean(strength, na.rm = T)) %>%tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = c(strength)) %>%arrange(value) %>%distinct(.) %>%ggplot(aes(value, reorder(category, value), fill = name)) +geom_segment(aes(xend = 0, yend = category)) +geom_point(size = 4, aes(color = category), show.legend = F) +geom_text(aes(label = round(value, 1)), hjust = -.5) +theme_minimal() +labs(x = "Strenght of Password", y = "Category of Password")passwords %>%filter(!is.na(password)) %>%mutate(num_digits = str_count(password, "\\d"), num_char = str_count(password, "\\D"), no_digits_char = str_count(password, "[^\\d] | [^\\D]"),type_of_pwd = case_when(num_digits == 0 & num_char > 0 ~ "Character only", num_digits > 0 & num_char == 0 ~ "Numeric only", num_digits > 0 & num_char > 0 ~ "Both Character & Numeric")) %>%count(category, type_of_pwd, name = "Freq") %>%ggplot(aes(Freq, category, fill = type_of_pwd)) +geom_col(width = .5, position = "dodge") +theme_minimal() +theme(legend.position = "bottom") +labs(x = "Category of Password", y = "Frequecy") +scale_fill_manual(values = c("#00AFBB", "#4E84C4", "#FC4E07"))Looks like majority of the passwords consist of only character values. Some of the password-related and sport related passwords have both the numeric and characters.The nerdy-pop passwords have the least number of passwords with numeric and simple-alphanumeric have the highest number of passwords with only numeric and also with both the numeric and characters.
passwords %>%filter(!is.na(password)) %>%mutate(num_digits = str_count(password, "\\d"), num_char = str_count(password, "\\D"), no_digits_char = str_count(password, "[^\\d] | [^\\D]"),type_of_pwd = case_when(num_digits == 0 & num_char > 0 ~ "Character only", num_digits > 0 & num_char == 0 ~ "Numeric only", num_digits > 0 & num_char > 0 ~ "Both Character & Numeric"),labz = case_when(value > 75 ~ password, TRUE ~ "")) %>%group_by(type_of_pwd, time_unit) %>%summarise(value = mean(value, na.rm = T)) %>%mutate(time_unit = factor(time_unit, levels = c("seconds", "minutes", "hours", "days", "weeks", "months", "years"))) %>%ggplot(aes(type_of_pwd, value, fill = time_unit)) +geom_col(position = "dodge") +theme_minimal() +theme(legend.position = "bottom") +labs(y = "Duration taken to crack password", x = NULL) +scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1", guide = guide_legend(nrow = 1)) +scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0, 0), limits = c(0, 60))Based on the data, its better to have a password that’s alpha numeric as it has a higher password strength and would take longer to crack as compared to passwords that are only consisting of numeric or only characters.
summary: We are going to look a dataset from the Tidytuesday on the passwords. The dataset entails the actual text of the password,the category of the password,time taken to crack the password(both online and offline) and the strength of the password.
title: #Tidytuesday Cracking Passwords
